title: Ringo Starr still gets emotional ‘some b***ard’ shot John Lennon
text:
Ringo still gets emotional over John’s murder

Ringo Starr has revealed he still gets emotional over the death of his Beatle’s bandmate John Lennon.

Feeling the presence of the singer and guitarist in his life, the drummer of the iconic band recalled becoming overwhelmed with emotion after he was presented with an unreleased track of John’s.

Handed over by producer Jack Douglas, Ringo revealed the recording of Grow Old With Me, from John’s 1980s Bermuda Tapes demos, showed the singer – who was shot dead in 1980 – was thinking of his mate.

Speaking to Foo Fighters’ Dave Grohl in conversation for Rolling Stone magazine, Ringo said: ‘The interesting thing is this guy Jack Douglas, the producer, brought this track of John’s to me just this year; I’d never heard it. So he’s still in my life. And so it’s on the new album.

‘But why he gave me this CD is [because] at the beginning, John says, “Oh, that would be great for Richard Starkey.”

The group in 1963 (Picture: Getty Images)

‘I well up every time I think [about it] — he’s talking about me. He says, “Hey, Ringo, this’d be great for you.” And I can’t help myself.

‘I’m emotional now thinking of him 40 years ago talking about me on his tape and thinking of me. The four of us were great friends with a couple of side issues. And it was far out.’

And, well, now we’re crying, too.

Ringo, 79, admitted he still feels emotional about the circumstances surrounding John’s death and the surreal aftermath.

John was killed in 1980 (Picture: Getty Images)

He recalled to Dave ‘When John went, I was in the Bahamas. I was getting a phone call from my stepkids in LA saying, “Something’s happened to John.” And then they called and said, “John’s dead.” And I didn’t know what to do.

‘And I still well up that some b*****d shot him. But I just said, “We’ve got to get a plane.”’

He continued: ‘We got a plane to New York, and you don’t know what you can do. We went to the apartment. “Anything we can do?” And [John’s wife] Yoko [Ono] just said, “Well, you just play with Sean. Keep Sean busy.” And that’s what we did. That’s what you think, “What do you do now?”’

Ringo said it was when he returned to LA he grieved and has since become an ‘old crybaby’, also recalling his final moments with fellow Beatle George Harrison, who died of cancer aged 58 in 2001.

‘And George, the same… I’m such an old crybaby. He’s laying there very ill — not long,’ Ringo said.

‘And I’ve got to go to Boston, ’cause my daughter’s having an operation. And so I said, “Well, you know, I’ve got to go, George,” and he says, “Do you want me to come with you?” You know, he’s dying in a bit, “Do you want me to come with you?” How many people say great things like that to you, really give themselves?’

Enlisting the help of the only other remaining Beatle, Sir Paul McCartney, Ringo asked him to perform on the version Grow Old With Me, on his new album, What’s My Name.

In a fitting tribute to the legacy of the group, they’ve got John on it from the demo recording, now Paul, and, according to Ringo, ‘Jack puts in a very recognisable George Harrison riff’.
